title: Present Perfect Simple or Continuous - for, since - 3
instructions: Complete the sentences with the verbs in brackets. Use B1present perfectB2, B1present perfect continuousB2 or B1past simpleB2.

sentence: (travel) to Planet Terminus for three months now. We should have arrived earlier, but our spaceship
explain: Corr: have been travelling. It's present perfect continuous because it's still in progress.
Corr: has broken. It's present perfect simple because we say how many times it has happened.

sentence: (not be) necessary in my new job. But there I

explain: Corr: did. It's past simple because this question is about a period that started and finished in the past.
Corr: learn. It's past simple because this question is about a period that started and finished in the past.
Corr: stopped. It's past simple because it was at the end of that four month period.

sentence: (come) to this spa bath for five years. We love it. Last year we
(come) here only once, but this year we
explain: Corr: have been coming. It's present perfect continuous because this action is still in progress and no quantity is mentioned.
Corr: came. It's past simple because of the time adverb 'last year'.

Corr: have been. It's present perfect simple. It's about an unfinished time period (this year, that is, since the beginning of this year), but it cannot be continuous because we say 'how many times we have done this'.

sentence: (get) this bar of chocolate only a minute ago, but I
(decide) to change my lifestyle, so perhaps that's why I crave it so much.
explain: Corr: got. It's past simple because of the adverb 'a minute ago'.

Corr: have eaten. It's present perfect because it's about a time period starting when he got the chocolate, and lasting until now. It cannot be continuous because we mention a quantity (the whole bar).
Corr: haven't eaten or haven't been eating. Both present perfect simple or continuous are acceptable. The continuous is emotionally loaded.
Corr: decided. It's past simple because in the 'since' clause we use past simple when we refer to a past event.

Corr: has never given. It's present perfect simple because it's about whether she has done something in her life or not.
